messageBody:
Jagdish Rao wrote:
> hello all
>
> hi i'm jagdish n i'm new to java development so dont get annoyed
> if i'm asking something silly
>
> The Prob : I have a swing based GUI called LoginView which is a
> typical login screen.i have written test cases to test the variuos
> conditions
> such as blank username and password or incorrect password.
>
> for this in my loginview class i am using the Joptionpane to display
> the
> alerts to user such as please enter data or incorrect password.
>
> now here when i run my test case the execution stops for the user to
> respond to Joptionpane.this is the problem
>
> i want to pass ok click to the test case(Incorrect password) so that
> testing wont require user intervention.
>
> please guide me if it is possible as i know it is a modal window
> or there r any other better way to achieve this
>
> something in the test case not in the GUI class which will do the
> needful

Here is my general approach to this problem. You want to /simulate/ (the
key word) pressing OK on a dialog. In your test, you want to invoke a
method like this:

...
optionPane.ok();
...

To do this, you need an /interface/ that exposes this method.

interface OptionPane {
void ok();
}

To use this, you need a /wrapper/ for JOptionPane that implements
OptionPane.

class MyOptionPane implements OptionPane {
private JOptionPane jOptionPane;

public MyOptionPane() {
// initialize jOptionPane...
}

public void show() {
jOptionPane.go();
}

public void ok() {
jOptionPane.click(OK): // Whatever the actual Swing code is
}
}

Now you need to be able inject an implementation of OptionPane into
whichever class was using JOptionPane directly...

class MyTask {
public MyTask(OptionPane optionPane) {
this.optionPane = optionPane;
...
}
...
}

Now you can pass MyTask a real MyOptionPane in production, but use a
fake OptionPane in your tests that doesn't actually require the user to
press a key.

I hope this helps.
